author: Cloverfied
body:
He talked about any or all "revolutions", noting Ford's industrial revolution in turning factories into production engines, have many car companies start and fail within a short time period.  He displayed a list of car companies throughout the early 1900's and noted that he wanted to show all the car companies that started up making cars with their name that started with the letter "M" but then found that there were so many within the letter "M" that he decided to take just the car companies that started with just "Ma" and had a large populated list of companies that started and failed in the automobile manufacturing business.

His opposition doesn't come from a new market being created, his opposition is in choosing who the winners of that market are going to be.  The ones that will return profits to investors over a period of time - hopefully enough time to return the investor's capital and then some.

Buffet doesn't "not understand" speculation.  He understands it just fine, his thesis is to invest in good companies that offer returns to shareholders based on the capital they have at risk.  He believes that in a world of thousands upon thousands of companies there is no need to take undue risks and that over a long period of time, making investments in quality companies with good management will return more profits than making a gamble on companies with a large amount of potential outcomes.  He believes his ability, or anyone's for that matter, to "pick" a winner based off so many unknown variables is completely at question and warns anyone to steer clear of said behavior.

Huh? That's not really a reply to what I've said. You did the same with the guy above who articulates my point much better.

I think clover will go up in the mid/long term with the MA age and expansion plan, but it's got a long hangover effect of spacmania and the seek insurance thing is a valid concern. I also think that since gme everything has become a "omg short interest" fiasco with people buying stocks expecting a repeat. It ain't going to happen every again, risk adjustment across the board already occurred (look at the jump in clov to 17).



So in summary, it is about making bets, but not about parroting useless shite like you have done. Buy shares if you think it'll go up, average down it it tanks post earnings. Don't expect a squeeze, gamma slides occur but less frequently than people would have you believe

author: therealoptionisyou
body:
I have been using 100 and 200 moving average crossing to filter stocks that might be recovering after dipping. The downside of this approach is that if the crossing doesn't happen today (I think) it won't show in the results. Also there are noises like stable stocks that fluctuate around the MA. I'm using TradingView.

Please let me know if anyone has a better approach!

author: cplange1
body:
>NASDAQ found support on the rising 100 day MA in March, yesterday it tested the 50 day and bounced. It's still stuck in a range and has been for a couple months now .

The reason I'm not using the 50 is that it hasn't generally respected the 50.  The lows tend to respect the 100-day during dips which tends to correspond closely with the trend line I drew.

I don't think we're looking at a major meltdown--there's nothing so catastrophic we'd hit correction that I know of, but I think there may be a modest pull back to consolidate after earnings as well as take profits (there could also be some rebalancing as well)

author: tockstocks
body:
No worries. I'm actually home sick right now (not Covid, just sinus infection) so I don't have much else to do, anyway. :)

1. They sent our practice a cold call email with the features and it seemed cool looking, so I tried it out. I tend to try lots of demos mostly just to see what is out there, but I never really have plans to make a full switch because we like ECW. It was more curiosity than a desire to switch, really. If it had been a platform that could have integrated directly into our EMR, that would have been better. 
2. We pay a quarterly licensing free for ECW and had/have some setup costs with new features. Overall, the expense is roughly $15k + $5k per provider, per year. I think the biggest hurdle is that it isn't using practice data, but insurance claim data. In theory, that should be the same, but it is definitely not in practice. We are also rather unique in that we don't participate with Medicare, so we have very few MA patients and wouldn't be able to use this for 95% of our patients. That point was probably my biggest reason for not adding one extra tool, even though it is free. At some point, there is just too much data and you can't expect employees to navigate it efficiently, so we stick with basic measures and just try to do really well on them. 
3. Nobody else has offered to pay us to use a service, so that is unique. Athena has a free EMR version, but it is ad-supported so our visit notes would look like they're sponsored by a drug company, which isn't a good look! The financial incentive selling points seem to be the ability to easily qualify for Medicare Meaningful Use, but we don't participate so that benefit doesn't help us. 
4. I have had more pitches for a direct contracting service in the last two months than I've had in 14 years, so I feel like a ton of companies are trying to jump on what they are as easy money. We are a part of an ACO, but are not subject to capitation. I think FFS is going away, but not until something like Medicare for All is passed. Not sure of the timeline there, but I'd expect 2023 to be the point where smaller primary cares actually start moving towards something like that. Our ACO has put December 2022 as their "you must promise to at least consider a capitation model" deadline, but we are not required to switch at that point. 

Lastly, because we don't take Medicare, I don't think we are exactly Clover's target market right now and may not be the best perspective on their sales pitch. All the commercial insurances are already doing their own similar thing, so they'll be competing with existing products from BCBS/Cigna/UHC/etc. if they ever mean to expand past Medicare.

author: jsfsmith
body:
There's a lot of misinformation about the VIE structure that's worth clearing up here. It is true that all of Alibaba's assets are privately owned by the founders of the company. However, those founders also hold BABA / HKG:9988, because the VIE has an exclusive contract to the profits of Alibaba. If you look up their 20-F SEC filing, you can see the exact number of shares owned by Jack Ma, Joseph Tsai, etc. 

There is no such thing as "Chinese Alibaba stock." It does not exist. It is only listed outside of China via the VIE structure. As such, the VIE is essentially Alibaba's main / only source of capital. Also, both the NYSE listing (BABA) and the HKEX listing (9988) are for the same Cayman Islands VIE. While the VIE does absolutely introduce a degree of uncertainty, Alibaba needs their foreign shareholders just as much as the foreign shareholders need Alibaba. It is in their best interests to keep the peace and keep shenanigans to a minimum.

author: Nerdicane
body:
MVIS is pure pump and dump. They have no product to market. They’re hoping to get bought by someone bigger.

Yahoo finance has, as of april 14th, FAMI having a 2% Short interest. The share offering accounts for the dip in price. So, theoretically, the short interest went from 2% to 130% and it didn’t affect the price. 

Not to mention this wasn’t a company the was overvalued or failing to begin with, which is usually what draws short attention. They’re just a tiny mushroom grower in China. Why would financial institutions target that?

Which brings me to the biggest factor for me, China. Every company in China is owned by China. They just allow business owners to think they own their company. Just ask Jack Ma. Or you could if he wasn’t still missing after 3 months. IF he shows back up I’m sure he’ll be much more pro-CCP. But I’m sure when he’s replaced , the new guy will certainly be. 

My philosophy is this: if there are inconsistent signals and it’s the CCP, stay the fuck away.

body:
Absolutely agree with your points. I do however think the capital intensive nature of the industry can be a benefit to the company as it creates a barrier to entry for potential competitors. 

Currency risk for me is the biggest concern I think, though my working assumption is in the long term these currencies should stabilise as the total economy grows. 

As you mentioned, the TPG and MasterCard investments were a fantastic piece of business too. Looking forward to see where this one goes long term, the numbers look like investors will be compensated heavily for the additional risk!

author: ExaltedNecrosis
body:
Yeah, that original statement is completely wrong. Even in the US, 40% of in-person transactions are cash. In Mexico, it's 90%. It's 82% in Austria and Germany.

There is still so, so much room to grow for companies that provide credit, debit, or online payments. That's why I'm super bullish on V, MA, SQ, PYPL, MELI, etc. It doesn't matter how much of the digital payments pie each of these has when the pie itself is going to grow by huge amounts in the future. Cash is still king in most of the world, but it's trending towards digital payments each year.
